original_text: However, the measured reflectivity is less than the predicted value (∼96%), which is likely to relate to, amongst other factors, the roughness of the GaN/AlN interfaces particularly for the first layer in the DBR stack and the non-uniformity of the DBR layer thicknesses. Using STEM measurements of the thickness of each layer (on the a-plane) through the thickness of the stack, we calculate a new model (green curve) in which the overall reflectivity is reduced to 85%. This implies that variations in layer thickness through the stack are the main source of the reduced reflectivity in comparison to the model. In fact, a closer look at the cross-sectional STEM data and a careful extraction of layer thickness have revealed that whilst the layer thicknesses are fairly consistent through the DBR stack in the wing regions, there is a monotonic variation in the measured layer thicknesses in the window regions. (The GaN layer width smoothly increases, while the AlN layer thickness decreases through the DBR stack.). This observation could potentially be of practical importance, for samples grown on templates with a uniform defect density, as one could achieve much better reflectivities simply by altering the growth time to counteract the change in growth rate. This possibility is the subject of ongoing investigations. In addition, the presence of cracks and trenches in the top surface may also reduce the measured reflectivity further.
original_translation: Sin embargo, la reflectividad medida es menor que el valor predicho (∼96%), lo cual probablemente se relaciona, entre otros factores, con la rugosidad de las interfaces GaN/AlN, especialmente para la primera capa en la pila de DBR, y la falta de uniformidad en los espesores de las capas de DBR. Usando medidas STEM del grosor de cada capa (en el plano a) a lo largo del espesor del apilamiento, calculamos un nuevo modelo (curva verde) en el que la reflectividad total se reduce al 85%. Esto implica que las variaciones en el grosor de las capas a lo largo del apilamiento son la principal fuente de la reflectividad reducida en comparación con el modelo. De hecho, un examen más detallado de los datos STEM transversales y una extracción cuidadosa del grosor de las capas han revelado que, si bien los grosores de las capas son bastante consistentes a lo largo de la pila DBR en las regiones de las alas, hay una variación monótona en los grosores de las capas medidos en las regiones de las ventanas. (El ancho de la capa de GaN aumenta suavemente, mientras que el grosor de la capa de AlN disminuye a lo largo de la pila DBR). Esta observación podría ser de importancia práctica, para muestras cultivadas en plantillas con una densidad uniforme de defectos, ya que se podría lograr reflectividades mucho mejores simplemente alterando el tiempo de crecimiento para contrarrestar el cambio en la velocidad de crecimiento. Esta posibilidad es el tema de investigaciones en curso. Además, la presencia de grietas y trincheras en la superficie superior también puede reducir aún más la reflectividad medida.

Using STEM measurements of the thickness of each layer (on the a-plane) through the thickness of the stack, we calculate a new model (green curve) in which the overall reflectivity is reduced to 85%.
This implies that variations in layer thickness through the stack are the main source of the reduced reflectivity in comparison to the model.

In fact, a closer look at the cross-sectional STEM data and a careful extraction of layer thickness have revealed that whilst the layer thicknesses are fairly consistent through the DBR stack in the wing regions, there is a monotonic variation in the measured layer thicknesses in the window regions. (The GaN layer width smoothly increases, while the AlN layer thickness decreases through the DBR stack.).

This observation could potentially be of practical importance, for samples grown on templates with a uniform defect density, as one could achieve much better reflectivities simply by altering the growth time to counteract the change in growth rate.
This possibility is the subject of ongoing investigations.
In addition, the presence of cracks and trenches in the top surface may also reduce the measured reflectivity further.

Usando medidas STEM del grosor de cada capa (en el plano a) a lo largo del espesor del apilamiento, calculamos un nuevo modelo (curva verde) en el que la reflectividad total se reduce al 85%. Esto implica que las variaciones en el grosor de las capas a lo largo del apilamiento son la principal fuente de la reflectividad reducida en comparación con el modelo. De hecho, un examen más detenido de los datos STEM transversales y una extracción cuidadosa del grosor de las capas han revelado que, si bien los grosores de las capas son bastante consistentes a lo largo del
apilamiento DBR en las regiones de las alas
, hay una variación monótona en los grosores de las capas medidas en las regiones de las ventanas. (El ancho de la capa de GaN aumenta suavemente, mientras que el grosor de la capa de AlN disminuye a lo largo del apilamiento DBR). Esta observación podría ser de importancia práctica, para muestras cultivadas en plantillas con una densidad uniforme de defectos, ya que se podría lograr reflectividades mucho mejores simplemente alterando el tiempo de crecimiento para contrarrestar el cambio en la velocidad de crecimiento. Esta posibilidad es el tema de investigaciones en curso. Además, la presencia de grietas y trincheras en la superficie superior también puede reducir aún más la reflectividad medida.

original_annotated_sentences: However, the measured reflectivity is less than the predicted value (∼96%), which is likely to relate to, amongst other factors, the roughness of the GaN/AlN interfaces particularly for the first layer in the DBR stack and the non-uniformity of the DBR layer thicknesses.
Using STEM measurements of the thickness of each layer (on the a-plane) through the thickness of the stack, we calculate a new model (green curve) in which the overall reflectivity is reduced to 85%.
This implies that variations in layer thickness through the stack are the main source of the reduced reflectivity in comparison to the model.

In fact, a closer look at the cross-sectional STEM data and a careful
extraction of layer thickness
have revealed that whilst the layer thicknesses are fairly consistent through the DBR stack in the wing regions, there is a monotonic variation in the measured layer thicknesses in the window regions. (The GaN layer width smoothly increases, while the AlN layer thickness decreases through the DBR stack.).

This observation could potentially be of practical importance, for samples grown on templates with a uniform defect density, as one could achieve much better reflectivities simply by altering the growth time to counteract the change in growth rate.
This possibility is the subject of ongoing investigations.
In addition, the presence of cracks and trenches in the top surface may also reduce the measured reflectivity further.

In fact, a closer look at the cross-sectional STEM data and a careful

have revealed that whilst the layer thicknesses are fairly consistent through the DBR stack in the wing regions, there is a monotonic variation in the measured layer thicknesses in the window regions. (The GaN layer width smoothly increases, while the AlN layer thickness decreases through the DBR stack.).
